intro: Reholttumia laticuneata, commonly known as the broad-leafed marsh grass, is a flowering plant native to wetland environments in Southeast Asia. It belongs to the Poaceae family, which includes grasses, and is characterized by its tall, slender stems and broad, lance-shaped leaves. The plant produces small, inconspicuous flowers arranged in spikelets, typical of grasses, and thrives in moist, nutrient-rich soils. It plays an important ecological role in stabilizing wetland soils and providing habitat for various microorganisms and invertebrates. Due to its adaptability, it is often found in marshes, swamps, and along the edges of water bodies.
